title: Cloud Computing with Google Earth Engine
text:
Introduction
These notes are intended to accompany the the Digital Life Sience Data Lab course. Nils will work with you through these examples in a workshop format. This means he will live code and you will accompany him. We specifically do not want to give you these codes up front, since writing your own code and making mistakes is the best way to learn.
This also means that the code you write is part of your learning experience and you should keep it for your own reference. To set this up, proceed as follows:
Instructions for Nils:

title: Cloud Computing with Google Earth Engine
text:
Preperation
Please make sure you have registered for a GoogleEarthEngine Account. See the slides here for instructions.

2  Demo 2: Html-file

6  Demo: Methods
text:
Methods are functions tied to specific objects.
var myname = "Nils Ratnaweera"

// in the console:
myname.length
var myage = 34
// in the console
myage.toFixed(2) // 2 decimal places
var myname = "Nils Ratnaweera"
// in the console
myname.split(" ")

myname.split("").reverse()

myname.split("").reverse().join("")

title: 7  Demo: year2days-Website
8  Task: Reverse-name
9  Demo 1: Unispectral Data
text: Setting up

title: 9  Demo 1: Unispectral Data
9  Demo 1: Unispectral Data
text:
console.log() and print()

Nothing happens.
To get metadata of the data (similar to R str() function):

console.log(srtm);

In the GEE environment, print() is the same as console.log()
This is not the case outside GEE!

print(srtm);

title: 9  Demo 1: Unispectral Data
text:
Create a map
Add the data to the map
Map.addLayer(srtm)

The result does not show much. Why?
The color scheme “white to black” is streched across the whole range of values.
Visp, however steep it is there, does not cover this whole range.

title: 9  Demo 1: Unispectral Data
section: Consult docs to change the viz params
text:
Consult docs to change the viz params

Truncate using the GUI interface (e.g. from 0 to 4000).
In the docs for Map.addLayer() see the reference:

For Images and ImageCollection, see ee.data.getMapId for valid parameters

Look for ee.data.getMapId in the docs and note the following reference:

The visualization parameters as a (client-side) JavaScript object. …

min (comma-separated numbers) Value (or one per band) to map onto 00.
max (comma-separated numbers) Value (or one per band) to map onto FF.



visParam = {min: 0, max: 4000}
Map.addLayer(srtm, visParam)

title: 9  Demo 1: Unispectral Data
text:
Add a color palette
Add a color palette, and maybe to the whole thing in one line:
Map.addLayer(srtm, {min: 0, max: 4000, palette: ["green", "red", "blue"]})

title: 9  Demo 1: Unispectral Data
10  Demo 2: Multispectral Data
text:
Exploring Multispectral Data

In this exercise, we will explore a more complex, multispectral dataset.
This adds complexity since there are not only multiple bands, but there also is a temporal dimension and issues with cloud cover etc

Lets get started!

Look for Sentinel-2 Data, browse the collections
Add the dataset * Harmonized Sentinel-2 MSI: MultiSpectral Instrument, Level-2A*

var s2 = ee.ImageCollection("COPERNICUS/S2_SR_HARMONIZED");

Even the first step shows us, that this is a more complex dataset.
Printing the collection fails:

print(s2);

in the docs, look for ways to filter the dataset, e.g. by date
use the function filterDate() which can be found under ee.ImageCollection
Apply the filter:

Play around with some recent dates (2 - 3 days)
Zoom out
and add the result to the map.
This nicely shows the path of the Sentiel-2 satellite


var filtered = s2.filterDate("2023-10-01", "2023-10-03");

Map.addLayer(filtered);

Printing to the console is still not possible.
How many images are in the collection?

print(filtered.size())

Zoom back to a region of interest, e.g. Visp
The image does not look good
Check the Docs for ee.ImageCollection and as before, it references ee.data.getMapId(). There, note the following line:

bands (comma-separated strings) Comma-delimited list of band names to be mapped to RGB.

Read the Metadata of the dataset, check the Tab “Bands”. Note the Band names and their description: RGB is “B4, B3, B2”.

Map.addLayer(filtered, {"bands":["B4","B3","B2"]});

still not looking good. Using the map UI, use the layer setting to strech the image to 98% and raise the gamma to about 4. You will learn more about these values in the Remote Sensing Course (FS24)
import these setting into the script via the Import-Button

Note the imageVisParam object and how it is part of the code, but not quite. You can copy the code and create your own object from it, if you are so inclined.
You can now replace the JavaScript object with the imageVisParam object


// was created automagically:
var imageVisParam = {"opacity":1,"bands":["B4","B3","B2"],"min":85.84,"max":4206.16,"gamma":3.055};

// can be used in the addLayer-function:
Map.addLayer(filtered, imageVisParam);

title: 11  Demo 3: Multispec NDVI
text: Setup

title: 11  Demo 3: Multispec NDVI
11  Demo 3: Multispec NDVI
11  Demo 3: Multispec NDVI
11  Demo 3: Multispec NDVI
text:
Inspect the output

Check the output of console.log(s2).
We wanted a single image, but still have an image collection with multiple values.
We might want to choose the best image (we will do so later on)
but for now let’s keep it simple and just take the first with the first() method

s2 = s2.first()

print(s2)

title: 11  Demo 3: Multispec NDVI
11  Demo 3: Multispec NDVI
11  Demo 3: Multispec NDVI
text:
Adjust range and palette

Via the GUI

Adjust the value range to -1 - 1
Add a palettte by adding the colors red, yellow and green. These will automatically be mapped to the specified value rage.

Import the visParams from the GUI to the code editor

imageVisParam2 = {"opacity":1,"bands":["B8"],"min":-1,"palette":["ff0000","ffff00","008000"]};

Map.addLayer(ndvi, imageVisParam2);

title: 11  Demo 3: Multispec NDVI
section: Normalized Difference Function (skip this, doesn’t work)
text:
Normalized Difference Function (skip this, doesn’t work)

Alternatively, you can use the Normalized Difference function
The function “normalizedDifference” is a generic function to calculcate normalized difference between two bands
This doesn’t seem to work?

var ndvi = s2.normalizedDifference(["B8", "B4"]);

title: 11  Demo 3: Multispec NDVI

text: Prepare

title: 12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
text:
Replace Point with Polygon

Delete the aoi-Point and replace it with a Polygon of the same name
Draw a polygon from about Lalden (North-East) to Zeneggen (South-West)
Rerun the code, the output should be similar

title: 12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
section: Apply the function to the whole image collection

title: 12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
text:
Visualize the output

Now we want to create a chart of the ndvi values over time
search through the docs for chart.
consult the docs “ui.Chart.image.series” first
Try the following

print(ui.Chart.image.series(ndvi, aoi));

title: 12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
text:
Debugging the chart
This will throw an error:






Error



No features contain non-null values of "system:time_start"

title: 12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
text:
Compare the two objects
Compare the to objects, s2 and ndvi. Much metadata was lost when we mapped the function over the collection.






s2 looks as follows:





features: List (218 elements)
  0:  Image COPERNICUS/S2_SR_HARMONIZED/20230101T102339_20230101T102333_T32TLS (23 bands)
    type: Image
    id: COPERNICUS/S2_SR_HARMONIZED/20230101T102339_20230101T102333_T32TLS
    version: 1696354178264204
    bands: List (23 elements)
    properties: Object (101 properties)  # ← lots of metadata
      AOT_RETRIEVAL_ACCURACY: 0
      AOT_RETRIEVAL_METHOD: CAMS
      ....
      system:time_end: 1672568887220
      system:time_start: 1672568887220









ndvi looks as follows:





features: List (218 elements)
  0: Image (1 band)
    type: Image
    bands: List (1 element)
    properties: Object (1 property)        # ← no metadata
      system:index: 20230101T102339_20230

title: 12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
section: Run analysis on the entire year
text:
Run analysis on the entire year

Now, extend the date range to the entire year
Note how the ndvi values change over time, but have irregularities?

9

title: 12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
text:
Filtering by cloud cover
This shows the issue: clouds!


Check the metadata of the image.
In the properties, there is a field CLOUDY_PIXEL_PERCENTAGE.
in the docs, look for Filters
ee.Filter.metadata(name, operator, value) is depricated, use ee.Filter.lt() instead

s2 = s2.filter(ee.Filter.lt('CLOUDY_PIXEL_PERCENTAGE', 20));

title: 12  Demo 4: NDVI over time
text:
Export the data
Now you can export the output as csv, svg or png

title: 13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
text: Preperation

title: 13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
text:
get dataset “Hansen Global Forest Change v1.9 (2000-2021)”
print() it to the console, explore the bands and properties

var hansen = ee.Image("UMD/hansen/global_forest_change_2020_v1_8")

print(hansen)

title: 13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
text:
Determin the area of interest

draw a square or a polygon around the forest fire in Leuk
rename it to aoi

title: 13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
section: Get Tree Canopy Cover over time

title: 13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
text:
Filter by aoi
// chaining!
var gfcc = ee.ImageCollection("NASA/MEASURES/GFCC/TC/v3")
  .select("tree_canopy_cover")
  .filterBounds(aoi)

print(gfcc.size())
print(gfcc)

title: 13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
section: Get the date of the first and last dataset

title: 13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
text:
Draw aoi outine

Look for fillcolor in the docs
notice that these can only be applied to FeatureCollections
read up on ee.FeatureCollection
notice that you can create a FeatureCollection from a Geometry
do this, and then style the aoi_fc using fillColor: "00000000"

var aoi_fc = ee.FeatureCollection(aoi)
Map.addLayer(aoi_fc, {fillColor: "00000000"}, "aoi");

title: 13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
text:
Work on Map

Add color ramp (e.g. gray to green), transparency and strech the values 0 - 100
Maybe highlight https://colorbrewer2.org

Map.addLayer(treeCanopy2000, imageVisParam, "2000");

title: 13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
text:
Create a chart

Comparing 2000 and 2015 already shows, that the tree canopy cover has not really increased
Lets determin the tree canopy cover over time by creating a chart

print(ui.Chart.image.series(gfcc, aoi));

title: 13  Demo 5: Forest regrowth
